title: What is the use of integration in mathematics? - Quora

response.answer_text: It is the reverse of differentiation, the rate of change of a function. [math]\displaystyle \frac d{dx} F(x) = f(x) \iff \int f(x) dx = F(x) + C \tag* {}[/math] This is called indefinite integration, where the constant is not determined yet because any primitive plus another constant yield the same derivative, so we always add +C towards the end of our answer to indicate that the constant is yet to be determined. However, you might have heard that integration is integral to calculate the area under a curve. That is called definite integration.  This is the notation for the area under consideration, but how do we calculate the area? It is originally defined to be the sum of areas of the rectangular strips when the width is approaching 0, which means something like this:  Hope you get the idea. But this does not work for all the functions, because it is extremely tedious to get the area in this way. So what we want to do is to consider the derivative of the area function starting from a fixed value of x. To consider that, we consider [math]A(x+h) - A(x)[/math] for a smaller value of h. It is basically a little strip with width h, which we would approximate that to be a rectangle. That means the area would be [math]\Delta A \approx f(x)\cdot h \tag*{}[/math] That means [math]\dfrac d{dx} A(x) = f(x) \tag*{}[/math]  This is called the fundamental theorem of calculus. There is just one bit to complete. To find the actual area, it seems that we are finding the integral, but according to the discussion in the very first bit of this answer, there is infinitely many answer differing by constants. To cope with this, if we have [math]\displaystyle \int^x_a f(t)dt = F(x) + C \tag*{} [/math] And replace [math]x[/math] by [math]a[/math], we should have the answer to be 0 because the area under the curve from x = a to x = a, should obviously be 0. So the required integration constant is [math]-F(a)[/math] In general we have [math]\displaystyle \int^b_a f(t)dt = F(b)-F(a) \tag*{}[/math] This is a crash course on what integration is about!
